talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Workforce Participation, in writing, on 12 May 2005:

item.para: What is the current unemployment rate for people with a disability.
How many, and what proportion of, Job Network Providers are devoted solely to assisting those with disabilities find employment.
What has been the percentage increase in the number of people with disabilities entering the workforce since the introduction of the Disability Discrimination Act a decade ago.
What measures are being taken to boost the number of Job Network Providers devoted solely to assisting those with disabilities find meaningful employment.
How many, and what proportion of, people with a disability are employed by Job Network Providers as advocates or in another capacity.
What is the Government’s current investment in assisting people with disabilities to secure employment and how does this compare with the OECD average.

Will the Government implement a key finding of its Employer Incentive Strategy to develop a public awareness campaign aimed particularly at employers to encourage the hiring of people with disabilities; if so, when.
What measures is the Government taking to counter negative employer attitudes that prevent economic participation for those with disabilities.

Is he aware that the proportion of Federal public servants with a disability has fallen from 5.8% to 3.8% during the period of the current Government and can he say what steps are being taken by the Government to reverse this decline.
Why has the Government delayed the training and employment measure announced in the 2002 Federal budget.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The unemployment rate for people with disabilities was 8.6% in 2003. (Australian Bureau of Statistics, 2003 Survey of Disability, Ageing and Carers Summary of Findings, 4430.0, table 8, p26). This is the latest available data.

There are 12 specialist Job Network providers who specialise in assisting people with disabilities, or particular types of disability. There are 37 sites nationally that service people with disabilities. These 12 specialist organisations account for 11% of all Job Network organisations.

The percentage increase in the number of people with disabilities entering the workforce from 1993 to 2003 is 38.1 per cent (Australian Bureau of Statistics, 2003 Survey of Disability, Ageing and Carers Summary of Findings, 4430.0, table 8, p26. 1998 Survey of Disability, Ageing and Carers Summary of Findings, 4430.0, table 9 p21 and 1993 Survey of Disability, Ageing and Carers Summary of Findings, 4430.0, table 9 p21).

All Job Network Members are required to provide services to people with disabilities. The Government is committed to ensuring job seekers with disabilities can access employment assistance as required.
The Department does not collect detailed information about the structure or staffing of Job Network Members.
The following table provides expenditure on employment assistance for people with disabilities in 2003-04.

quote.para: *Expenditure figures for open employment services and open and supported services are actual expenditure figures.
^The expenditure figure for business services is estimated expenditure provided by the Department of Family and Community Services.
#Data was not disaggregated between open and supported employment services for outlets that provided both (dual).

item.para: In addition, in excess of $40 million was expended for job seekers with a disability in the Job Network in 2003-04.

The OECD do not provide data on the OECD average for expenditure on employment programs for people with disabilities due to data limitations. Country comparisons are difficult due to programs being run at regional, municipal, or national level and respective statistics expenditure is either unavailable or hard to obtain. (OECD Transforming Disability into Ability – Policies to Promote Work and Income Security for Disabled People 2003 p49).

(7) In the 2005 Budget, the Government provided $50 million over four years for the employer demand strategy. The strategy has three components aimed at increasing workforce participation for targeted groups in key industries and includes improving employer awareness of the benefits of hiring people with disabilities. The strategy includes:

a focus on those industries that have greatest potential to provide employment opportunities for people with disabilities such as those with a part-time or casual workforce and who are experiencing labour and skill shortages;
in collaboration with industry groups, employers and employment service providers developing practical solutions to recruit people with a disability to address labour and skill shortages;
showcasing to other industry groups, employers and employment service providers successful strategies to recruit and retain people with a disability
In addition, the Government will provide $29 million over four years to implement a communication strategy focusing on increasing workforce participation.
(8) The Government has already funded a number of pilot projects, training and employment strategies for people with a disability under the Employment Innovation Fund (EIF).
As announced in the 2005 Budget, $50 million is being provided for the employer demand strategy to promote the employment of people with disabilities.

The Government has also established an Employer Roundtable for people with disabilities to provide high level advice on ways to increase workforce participation for people with disabilities. The Employer Roundtable is made up of employers and peak bodies and is responsible for developing an action plan to drive employer demand for people with a disability.
(9) Yes. The number of people with a disability in the Australian Public Service has been in decline since 1990.

A number of measures are in place to promote the recruitment and retention of people with disabilities into the Australian Public Service. All Australian Government agencies are required, as part of the Commonwealth Disability Strategy, to remove barriers for people with a disability by ensuring access to buildings, services, information, employment, education, sport and recreational activities. The Public Service Commissioner’s Directions require that Agency heads put in place measures to prevent discrimination in their workplace and recognise the positive advantages of diversity in the workplace. The Public Service Commissioner is also a member of the recently formed Employer Roundtable for People with Disabilities.

(10) The $258 million announced in the 2002 Budget for employment services and training places was part of a package of reform to help people with disabilities. When the Opposition blocked the legislation for the reforms to the Disability Support Pension it also blocked the associated funding.
As part of the Welfare to Work package announced in the 2005 Budget, the Government has allocated $482.3 million over four years for employment related assistance for people with disabilities.

quote.para: *Expenditure figures for open employment services and open and supported services are actual expenditure figures.
^The expenditure figure for business services is estimated expenditure provided by the Department of Family and Community Services.
#Data was not disaggregated between open and supported employment services for outlets that provided both (dual).

item.para: In addition, in excess of $40 million was expended for job seekers with a disability in the Job Network in 2003-04.

The OECD do not provide data on the OECD average for expenditure on employment programs for people with disabilities due to data limitations. Country comparisons are difficult due to programs being run at regional, municipal, or national level and respective statistics expenditure is either unavailable or hard to obtain. (OECD Transforming Disability into Ability – Policies to Promote Work and Income Security for Disabled People 2003 p49).

(7) In the 2005 Budget, the Government provided $50 million over four years for the employer demand strategy. The strategy has three components aimed at increasing workforce participation for targeted groups in key industries and includes improving employer awareness of the benefits of hiring people with disabilities. The strategy includes:

a focus on those industries that have greatest potential to provide employment opportunities for people with disabilities such as those with a part-time or casual workforce and who are experiencing labour and skill shortages;
in collaboration with industry groups, employers and employment service providers developing practical solutions to recruit people with a disability to address labour and skill shortages;
showcasing to other industry groups, employers and employment service providers successful strategies to recruit and retain people with a disability
In addition, the Government will provide $29 million over four years to implement a communication strategy focusing on increasing workforce participation.
(8) The Government has already funded a number of pilot projects, training and employment strategies for people with a disability under the Employment Innovation Fund (EIF).
As announced in the 2005 Budget, $50 million is being provided for the employer demand strategy to promote the employment of people with disabilities.

The Government has also established an Employer Roundtable for people with disabilities to provide high level advice on ways to increase workforce participation for people with disabilities. The Employer Roundtable is made up of employers and peak bodies and is responsible for developing an action plan to drive employer demand for people with a disability.
(9) Yes. The number of people with a disability in the Australian Public Service has been in decline since 1990.

A number of measures are in place to promote the recruitment and retention of people with disabilities into the Australian Public Service. All Australian Government agencies are required, as part of the Commonwealth Disability Strategy, to remove barriers for people with a disability by ensuring access to buildings, services, information, employment, education, sport and recreational activities. The Public Service Commissioner’s Directions require that Agency heads put in place measures to prevent discrimination in their workplace and recognise the positive advantages of diversity in the workplace. The Public Service Commissioner is also a member of the recently formed Employer Roundtable for People with Disabilities.

(10) The $258 million announced in the 2002 Budget for employment services and training places was part of a package of reform to help people with disabilities. When the Opposition blocked the legislation for the reforms to the Disability Support Pension it also blocked the associated funding.
As part of the Welfare to Work package announced in the 2005 Budget, the Government has allocated $482.3 million over four years for employment related assistance for people with disabilities.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, in writing, on 23 May 2005:

item.para: Have there been any safety incidents for aircraft approaching or departing Townsville Airport in the last 18 months; if so, what are the details.

Has there been an incident where a passenger jet aircraft received a terrain warning advisory because it descended below the specified approach path, or a similar type of incident; if so, what are the details.

talker.name: Anderson, John, MP
talker.role: Minister for Transport and Regional Services
talker.name: Mr Anderson

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member’s question is as follows:

item.para: The details of safety incidents for aircraft approaching or departing Townsville Airport for the period 24 November 2003 to 23 May 2005 are set out in the two attached tables of records from the Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) and Australian Defence Force Defence Flight Safety (DFS).

The details of Ground Proximity Warning System (GPWS) related occurrences reported to the Australian Transport Safety Bureau during the period 24 November 2003 to 23 May 2005 are set out in the two attached tables of all GPWS occurrences and approach path related occurrences.
*The tables have been provided to the member, and are available from the House of Representaties Table Office
